-l-=1L9- Newark, Del The house is As by SO
feet two stores high, nearly new, handsomely pan-
ed. and in excellent order, with neat enclosure
in front, and another at the back and one the ends.
On the first floor there four rooms, and on
second, five. The appurtenances are. conveniert
kitchen Joining the house, stable carriage house,
&c The lot contains three acres, and well SIT
in timothy and cover.
Part the building was formerly occupied as a
store. for which it is the best stand in the village:
but for the last five years the whole has been
pied as female Boarding School. To this purpose
it is peculiarly adapted. the school room being AIRY
and spacious, the other apartments large enough for
the comfortable accommodation of more than twenty
boarders and the high enclosure in the rear afford
ing to the scholars convenient place of exercise and
recreation. A more eligible situation for board
ing school, either of boys girls could not easily
be found, The Village is healthy and pleasant, and
the surrounding country beautiful and neiy cutiva
ted.


10 a merchant, teacher, or parent desirous of
giving his sons classical education, this property
presents great advantages. will be given

nu4 Der of children in Delaware. All we want

nd Teacher. equal to the amount receired from L

is about | dollars. These taxes the State 4,

ny er County or State taxes.

NOTICE

GOVERNOR SCHULTZE.--lt would appear
rom the suhjoined article from Stephen Simpsons
paper, that Governor Schultzes marked out for sac
iiice by the violent leaders of the jackson party OF
Pennsylvania but they will find themselves most
wofully mistaken in their calculations. The patr-
otc devotion Of thls virtuous and enlightened Chlet
Magistrate to that policy which has distinguished
he steady course Of Pennsylvania for years, has en-
feared him to her citizens by tie which is not to
be broken by the malignant rawlings of such men as
those who have combined to immediate him. The
name of Gov. SCHULTZE will live in the CRATE
nl recolections Of the people of Pennsylvania. when
those who are his revllers will only be remembered
to be despi,pd.


From The Philadelphia Mcrcury. Dec. IS.


"That Mr.. Schultze has been opposed to Jackson,
is matter IF of0riety throughout the state and his
opposition is soamnly recorded, not only in his mes
-age of 1926, bat in that of the present year."
1T resolves itself ln'o the simple question, whc
ther the people ot Pennsylvania have greater re-
gard for Gen Jackson, or for Mr. schutze."

depressio might have serious consequences to largo
holders of the Stock. it is less than anticipated
BY two O'Clock his day ii will be yet lower at New
York. and by two o'clock Tomorrow it will be high
er than it was before began to decline. So sen
c Sitive plant is public credit, that even breat
y blasts it. ib.

We have received information from most res
pectable source. on which the utnos confidence can
be placed that vessel from Tuckertcn, New Jer--
sey, was lying at the wharfin NcwYork. during the
late election in that city that nine vt the men ON
board Of her. acbo ue IN N"n Jersey. at the press
ing entreaties of some persons in New York. were
induced to vote the Jackson cket and that each
Of them did actually it in three different wards
IT the city, making twenty Illegal votes, from
on board single vessel. How ma'y more. of the
crews passengers of the numerous vessels belong


ing to New Jersey. then in New York voted. it is diff
icult to determine but doubtless there were
ny. Our informant pledges hsnself for the truth Of
the above account. which he says be established
by poslthe testimony.

By adopting this policy. you will prevent measur-

THE SECRET OUT AT LAST In the pro-
ceedings of the JACKSON MEETING, held at
Chesterown, on the i5th inst. whereof William
Camp, Esq. was Chairman. we find the following
among other resolutions. After this let it not be
said that the Jackson are not opposed to the
encouragement Of Home Industry.


The 9TH resolution reads thus -


s'That we viev with the Hueiest alarm the unre-
ceding march of OPPRESSION under the specous
mask of encouragement of DOMESTIC lNDs s.
FRY, and the drusive name Of the ".4nlericon Sys-
tens," policy prosrative of Agriculture and Com
merce. and totally destructive of that harmony
which so necessary to the preservation OF this un-
ion."


The 10th is in these words =


THAT we cordially unite with our iellow-citizens
the agriculturIsts Of the South. in deprecating a
state of things which will ne,itaby lead to long
tram of evils, terminating in remonstrance. resis-
ance, and iaaiIy in dismemberment of our happy
union" !"


| As we shall touch these proceedings when we
have more time and space. we shall conclude by as
king, is the above the language Of patriotism !

will discover that politicians, looking to their own

resting to the people Of Delaware. aud therefore

for the politicians.


To any MEMBER of the DELAWARE LEGISLATURE


who feels proper interest in COMMON Schools.


LETTER III.


Dear Sir,


In my last, it was shown, l think clearly.
that NcwYork with our School Fund would
educate $1,000 children; and the State of
Maine 10000 children. or ten times the whole
nu4 Der of children in Delaware. All we want
is to provide for the education of IA 600. or at
most 5000, and yet we are constantly told
''thc Fund is too small, nothing as yet can be
DONE" Now what can be more evident than
that these opinions are groundless. Surety the
Fund ought to go as far here as a similar
amount in NewYork or Maine. or Massachus-
ctts. All we want is some leading man, OF
men to put the fund in operation. But how
shall this be done By 1Uhat ingenious plan i,
SD mach good accomplished by funds considerabl,
less than ours lin proportion to the population


in other States. The plan is among the sim
plest in the world.


The difficulty Of organizing a school district


and establishing school in some places. wa
hntcd at in former letter. The many vii
, not help the few. Now it is a duty which al
awe to the State to join their hands and heart


in promoting education throughout their owl


ncighborhood and the State ought 10 see to it
that erery citizen does bear his proporfion Of


burden so necessary to the 1oelfare Of the common
2 7cealh. 1t is upon this principle the New
;. York and other school systems are founded
d The State, by Commissioners chosen for tn

d into School Districts of "A proper size and ey


tent. This is the first thing. The next is t
Of notify all the freeholdcrs in that district to hol

- and there or. aniZe themselves according


law. Thus organized. the meeting has poWt

of the necessary sum to build School tIous


If a suitable one, in a suitable place. be M
rn already built. In New-York the sum thus Il
rs We'd must not exceed 400 dollars The Sclo
NJ House. once built. they are also empowered
,e- lay tax on the District. for the support Of
nd Teacher. equal to the amount receired from L
= State. This amount in New-York at prese


is about | dollars. These taxes the State 4,
=" thorizcs them to collect in the same way as OF
ny er County or State taxes.


Thus by a very light burden. and an ecu
at division Of expense, the whole community is i
uh Huenccd to tax and help itself in the support
nm. common schools In this way every memb
~ -. Of community is brought into contact with
'' school; and from being supporter, he so
ec' becomes a voluntary promoter of general ed
are cation. Some may perhaps imagine. that


donation from the State is so tritling. that Fl


districts will deem it worth while to take t

From the Mrylonder
full articles.article:
GOVERNOR SCHULTZE.--lt would appear
rom the suhjoined article from Stephen Simpsons
paper, that Governor Schultzes marked out for sac
iiice by the violent leaders of the jackson party OF
Pennsylvania but they will find themselves most
wofully mistaken in their calculations. The patr-
otc devotion Of thls virtuous and enlightened Chlet
Magistrate to that policy which has distinguished
he steady course Of Pennsylvania for years, has en-
feared him to her citizens by tie which is not to
be broken by the malignant rawlings of such men as
those who have combined to immediate him. The
name of Gov. SCHULTZE will live in the CRATE
nl recolections Of the people of Pennsylvania. when
those who are his revllers will only be remembered
to be despi,pd.


From The Philadelphia Mcrcury. Dec. IS.


"That Mr.. Schultze has been opposed to Jackson,
is matter IF of0riety throughout the state and his
opposition is soamnly recorded, not only in his mes
-age of 1926, bat in that of the present year."
1T resolves itself ln'o the simple question, whc
ther the people ot Pennsylvania have greater re-
gard for Gen Jackson, or for Mr. schutze."


From, the National MteMgencer, Dec l4th.


B4uoN DE KRuDENER. appointed Env " Extraor.
dinarv and Minister P!enpotentlary of His Imperi.
al Majesty the Emperor OF all the Russlas. near this
Government. was, on Saturday last. presented by
Mr. CLAY. Secretary of State, to the President Of


he United States. anil received in his official char
acter.


We observe that the news of Mr.. BARBOUR mo.
tion in the House of Representatives. to inquire in
to the expedency Of selling out the U. S. shares in
The Bank of the United States, depressed the Stock
of that Bank in the New York Market, by Friday
! last, from 25i to oil per cent Though even this
depressio might have serious consequences to largo
holders of the Stock. it is less than anticipated
BY two O'Clock his day ii will be yet lower at New
York. and by two o'clock Tomorrow it will be high
er than it was before began to decline. So sen
c Sitive plant is public credit, that even breat
y blasts it. ib.

We have received information from most res
pectable source. on which the utnos confidence can
be placed that vessel from Tuckertcn, New Jer--
sey, was lying at the wharfin NcwYork. during the
late election in that city that nine vt the men ON
board Of her. acbo ue IN N"n Jersey. at the press
ing entreaties of some persons in New York. were
induced to vote the Jackson cket and that each
Of them did actually it in three different wards
IT the city, making twenty Illegal votes, from
on board single vessel. How ma'y more. of the
crews passengers of the numerous vessels belong


ing to New Jersey. then in New York voted. it is diff
icult to determine but doubtless there were
ny. Our informant pledges hsnself for the truth Of
the above account. which he says be established
by poslthe testimony.
